repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
- Added `@inlinedoc` so single use Lua types can be inlined into the
  functions docs. E.g.

  ```lua
  --- @class myopts
  --- @inlinedoc
  ---
  --- Documentation for some field
  --- @field somefield integer

  --- @param opts myOpts
  function foo(opts)
  end
  ```

  Will be rendered as

  ```
  foo(opts)

    Parameters:
      - {opts} (table) Object with the fields:
               - somefield (integer) Documentation
                 for some field
  ```

- Marked many classes with with `@nodoc` or `(private)`.
  We can eventually introduce these when we want to.

comment_data.body: I'm aware these indentation errors need fixing.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -966,6 +966,112 @@ register({lang}, {filetype})              *vim.treesitter.language.register()*
 ==============================================================================
 Lua module: vim.treesitter.query                        *lua-treesitter-query*
 
+*vim.treesitter.Query*
+    Parsed query, see |vim.treesitter.query.parse()|
+
+    Fields: ~
+      â€¢ {lang}           (`string`) name of the language for this parser
+      â€¢ {captures}       (`string[]`) list of (unique) capture names defined
+                         in query
+      â€¢ {info}           (`vim.treesitter.QueryInfo`) contains information
+                         used in the query (e.g. captures, predicates,
+                         directives)
+      â€¢ {query}          (`TSQuery`) userdata query object
+      â€¢ {iter_captures}  (`fun(self: vim.treesitter.Querynode: TSNodesource:
+                         integer|stringstart: integer?stop: integer?):
+                         fun(end_line: integer?): integer, TSNode,
+                         vim.treesitter.query.TSMetadata`) Iterate over all
+                         captures from all matches inside {node}
+
+ {source} is needed if the query contains predicates;

comment_data.body:
I want to inline this but the issue is that this is used as:

```
---@param results table<integer, vim.lsp.CodeActionResultEntry>
```

So we kind of need to document the class. We could maybe try to inline this documentation a bit differently so the name is preserved?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1109,9 +939,259 @@ with({handler}, {override_config})                            *vim.lsp.with()*
                            behavior of the {handler}
 
 
+==============================================================================
+Lua module: vim.lsp.client                                        *lsp-client*
+
+*vim.lsp.Client*
+
+    Fields: ~
+      â€¢ {id}                    (`integer`) The id allocated to the client.
+      â€¢ {name}                  (`string`) If a name is specified on creation,
+                                that will be used. Otherwise it is just the
+                                client id. This is used for logs and messages.
+      â€¢ {rpc}                   (`vim.lsp.rpc.PublicClient`) RPC client
+                                object, for low level interaction with the
+                                client. See |vim.lsp.rpc.start()|.
+      â€¢ {offset_encoding}       (`string`) The encoding used for communicating
+                                with the server. You can modify this in the
+                                `config`'s `on_init` method before text is
+                                sent to the server.
+      â€¢ {handlers}              (`table<string,lsp.Handler>`) The handlers
+                                used by the client as described in
+                                |lsp-handler|.
+      â€¢ {requests}              (`table<integer,{ type: string, bufnr:
+                                integer, method: string}>`) The current
+                                pending requests in flight to the server.
+                                Entries are key-value pairs with the key being
+                                the request ID while the value is a table with
+                                `type`, `bufnr`, and `method` key-value pairs.
+                                `type` is either "pending" for an active
+                                request, or "cancel" for a cancel request. It
+                                will be "complete" ephemerally while executing
+                                |LspRequest| autocmds when replies are
+                                received from the server.
+      â€¢ {config}                (`vim.lsp.ClientConfig`) copy of the table
+                                that was passed by the user to
+                                |vim.lsp.start_client()|.
+      â€¢ {server_capabilities}   (`lsp.ServerCapabilities?`) Response from the
+                                server sent on initialize` describing the
+                                server's capabilities.
+      â€¢ {progress}              (`vim.lsp.Client.Progress`) A ring buffer
+                                (|vim.ringbuf()|) containing progress messages
+                                sent by the server.
+      â€¢ {initialized}           (`true?`)
+      â€¢ {workspace_folders}     (`lsp.WorkspaceFolder[]?`) The workspace
+                                folders configured in the client when the
+                                server starts. This property is only available
+                                if the client supports workspace folders. It
+                                can be `null` if the client supports workspace
+                                folders but none are configured.
+      â€¢ {root_dir}              (`string`)
+      â€¢ {attached_buffers}      (`table<integer,true>`)
+      â€¢ {commands}              (`table<string,fun(command: lsp.Command, ctx:
+                                table)>`) Table of command name to function
+                                which is called if any LSP action (code
+                                action, code lenses, ...) triggers the
+                                command. Client commands take precedence over
+                                the global command registry.
+      â€¢ {settings}              (`table`)
+      â€¢ {flags}                 (`table`)
+      â€¢ {get_language_id}       (`fun(bufnr: integer, filetype: string): string`)
+      â€¢ {capabilities}          (`lsp.ClientCapabilities`) The capabilities
+                                provided by the client (editor or tool)
+      â€¢ {dynamic_capabilities}  (`lsp.DynamicCapabilities`)
+      â€¢ {request}               (`fun(method: string, params: table?, handler:
+                                lsp.Handler?, bufnr: integer): boolean,
+                                integer?`) Sends a request to the server. This
+                                is a thin wrapper around {client.rpc.request}
+                                with some additional checking. If {handler} is
+                                not specified, If one is not found there, then
+                                an error will occur. Returns: {status},
+                                {[client_id]}. {status} is a boolean
+                                indicating if the notification was successful.
+                                If it is `false`, then it will always be
+                                `false` (the client has shutdown). If {status}
+                                is `true`, the function returns {request_id}
+                                as the second result. You can use this with
+                                `client.cancel_request(request_id)` to cancel
+                                the request.
+      â€¢ {request_sync}          (`fun(method: string, params: table?,
+                                timeout_ms: integer?, bufnr: integer): {err:
+                                lsp.ResponseError?, result:any}?, string?`)
+                                err # a dictionary, where
+      â€¢ {notify}                (`fun(method: string, params: table?):
+                                boolean`) Sends a notification to an LSP
+                                server. Returns: a boolean to indicate if the
+                                notification was successful. If it is false,
+                                then it will always be false (the client has
+                                shutdown).
+      â€¢ {cancel_request}        (`fun(id: integer): boolean`) Cancels a
+                                request with a given request id. Returns: same
+                                as `notify()`.
+      â€¢ {stop}                  (`fun(force?: boolean)`) Stops a client,
+                                optionally with force. By default, it will
+                                just ask the server to shutdown without force.
+                                If you request to stop a client which has
+                                previously been requested to shutdown, it will
+                                automatically escalate and force shutdown.
+      â€¢ {on_attach}             (`fun(bufnr: integer)`) Runs the on_attach
+                                function from the client's config if it was
+                                defined. Useful for buffer-local setup.
+      â€¢ {supports_method}       (`fun(method: string, opts?: {bufnr:
+                                integer?}): boolean`) Checks if a client
+                                supports a given method. Always returns true
+                                for unknown off-spec methods. [opts] is a
+                                optional `{bufnr?: integer}` table. Some
+                                language server capabilities can be file
+                                specific.
+      â€¢ {is_stopped}            (`fun(): boolean`) Checks whether a client is
+                                stopped. Returns: true if the client is fully
+                                stopped.
+
+*vim.lsp.Client.Progress*
+    Base class `vim.Ringbuf`
+
+    Fields: ~
+      â€¢ {pending}  (`table<lsp.ProgressToken,lsp.LSPAny>`)
+
+*vim.lsp.ClientConfig*
+
+    Fields: ~
+      â€¢ {cmd}                 (`string[]|fun(dispatchers:
+                              vim.lsp.rpc.Dispatchers):
+                              vim.lsp.rpc.PublicClient?`) command string[]
+                              that launches the language server (treated as in
+                              |jobstart()|, must be absolute or on `$PATH`,
+                              shell constructs like "~" are not expanded), or
+                              function that creates an RPC client. Function
+                              receives a `dispatchers` table and returns a
+                              table with member functions `request`, `notify`,
+                              `is_closing` and `terminate`. See
+                              |vim.lsp.rpc.request()|, |vim.lsp.rpc.notify()|.
+                              For TCP there is a builtin RPC client factory:
+                              |vim.lsp.rpc.connect()|
+      â€¢ {cmd_cwd?}            (`string`) Directory to launch the `cmd`
+                              process. Not related to `root_dir`. (default:
+                              |getcwd()|)
+      â€¢ {cmd_env?}            (`table`) Environment flags to pass to the LSP
+                              on spawn. Must be specified using a table.
+                              Non-string values are coerced to string.
+                              Example: >lua
+                                  { PORT = 8080; HOST = "0.0.0.0"; }
+<
+      â€¢ {detached?}           (`boolean`) Daemonize the server process so that
+                              it runs in a separate process group from Nvim.
+                              Nvim will shutdown the process on exit, but if
+                              Nvim fails to exit cleanly this could leave
+                              behind orphaned server processes. (default:
+                              true)
+      â€¢ {workspace_folders?}  (`lsp.WorkspaceFolder[]`) List of workspace
+                              folders passed to the language server. For
+                              backwards compatibility rootUri and rootPath
+                              will be derived from the first workspace folder
+                              in this list. See `workspaceFolders` in the LSP
+                              spec.
+      â€¢ {capabilities?}       (`lsp.ClientCapabilities`) Map overriding the
+                              default capabilities defined by
+                              |vim.lsp.protocol.make_client_capabilities()|,
+                              passed to the language server on initialization.
+                              Hint: use make_client_capabilities() and modify
+                              its result.
+                              â€¢ Note: To send an empty dictionary use
+                                |vim.empty_dict()|, else it will be encoded as
+                                an array.
+      â€¢ {handlers?}           (`table<string,function>`) Map of language
+                              server method names to |lsp-handler|
+      â€¢ {settings?}           (`table`) Map with language server specific
+                              settings. These are returned to the language
+                              server if requested via
+                              `workspace/configuration`. Keys are
+                              case-sensitive.
+      â€¢ {commands?}           (`table<string,fun(command: lsp.Command, ctx:
+                              table)>`) Table that maps string of clientside
+                              commands to user-defined functions. Commands
+                              passed to start_client take precedence over the
+                              global command registry. Each key must be a
+                              unique command name, and the value is a function
+                              which is called if any LSP action (code action,
+                              code lenses, ...) triggers the command.
+      â€¢ {init_options?}       (`table`) Values to pass in the initialization
+                              request as `initializationOptions`. See
+                              `initialize` in the LSP spec.
+      â€¢ {name?}               (`string`) Name in log messages. (default:
+                              client-id)
+      â€¢ {get_language_id?}    (`fun(bufnr: integer, filetype: string):
+                              string`) Language ID as string. Defaults to the
+                              filetype.
+      â€¢ {offset_encoding?}    (`'utf-8'|'utf-16'|'utf-32'`) The encoding that
+                              the LSP server expects. Client does not verify
+                              this is correct.
+      â€¢ {on_error?}           (`fun(code: integer, err: string)`) Callback
+                              invoked when the client operation throws an
+                              error. `code` is a number describing the error.
+                              Other arguments may be passed depending on the
+                              error kind. See `vim.lsp.rpc.client_errors` for
+                              possible errors. Use
+                              `vim.lsp.rpc.client_errors[code]` to get
+                              human-friendly name.
+      â€¢ {before_init?}        (`vim.lsp.client.before_init_cb`) Callback
+                              invoked before the LSP "initialize" phase, where
+                              `params` contains the parameters being sent to
+                              the server and `config` is the config that was
+                              passed to |vim.lsp.start_client()|. You can use
+                              this to modify parameters before they are sent.
+      â€¢ {on_init?}            (`elem_or_list<vim.lsp.client.on_init_cb>`)
+                              Callback invoked after LSP "initialize", where
+                              `result` is a table of `capabilities` and
+                              anything else the server may send. For example,
+                              clangd sends `initialize_result.offsetEncoding`
+                              if `capabilities.offsetEncoding` was sent to it.
+                              You can only modify the `client.offset_encoding`
+                              here before any notifications are sent.
+      â€¢ {on_exit?}            (`elem_or_list<vim.lsp.client.on_exit_cb>`)
+                              Callback invoked on client exit.
+                              â€¢ code: exit code of the process
+                              â€¢ signal: number describing the signal used to
+                                terminate (if any)
+                              â€¢ client_id: client handle
+      â€¢ {on_attach?}          (`elem_or_list<vim.lsp.client.on_attach_cb>`)
+                              Callback invoked when client attaches to a
+                              buffer.
+      â€¢ {trace?}              (`'off'|'messages'|'verbose'`) Passed directly
+                              to the language server in the initialize
+                              request. Invalid/empty values will (default:
+                              "off")
+      â€¢ {flags?}              (`table`) A table with flags for the client. The
+                              current (experimental) flags are:
+                              â€¢ allow_incremental_sync (bool, default true):
+                                Allow using incremental sync for buffer edits
+                              â€¢ debounce_text_changes (number, default 150):
+                                Debounce didChange notifications to the server
+                                by the given number in milliseconds. No
+                                debounce occurs if nil
+                              â€¢ exit_timeout (number|boolean, default false):
+                                Milliseconds to wait for server to exit
+                                cleanly after sending the "shutdown" request
+                                before sending kill -15. If set to false, nvim
+                                exits immediately after sending the "shutdown"
+                                request to the server.
+      â€¢ {root_dir?}           (`string`) Directory where the LSP server will
+                              base its workspaceFolders, rootUri, and rootPath
+                              on initialization.
+
+
+
 ==============================================================================
 Lua module: vim.lsp.buf                                              *lsp-buf*
 
+*vim.lsp.CodeActionResultEntry*

comment_data.body: Vimception :D
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -233,11 +234,33 @@ definitions.  The |lua-vim| :help is generated from the docstrings.
 
 Docstring format:
 - Use LuaCATS annotations: https://luals.github.io/wiki/annotations/
-- Limited markdown is supported.
-  - List-items start with `-` (useful to nest or "indent")
+- Markdown is supported.
 - Use ``` for code samples.
   Code samples can be annotated as `vim` or `lua`
 - Use `@nodoc` to prevent documentation generation.
+- Use `@inlinedoc` to inline `@class` blocks into `@param` blocks.
+  E.g. >lua
+      --- Object with fields:
+      --- @class myopts
+      --- @inlinedoc
+      ---
+      --- Documentation for some field
+      --- @field somefield? integer
+
+      --- @param opts? myOpts
+      function foo(opts)
+      end
+<
+
+  Will be rendered as: >vimdoc

comment_data.body: Is there a difference if the `@inlinedoc` is before the class definition?

comment_data.body: Should we maybe add (and is it worth it) a CI check to ensure all Lua types are namespaced correctly?

comment_data.body:
Shouldn't be. The parser just looks for contiguous blocks of comments, and `@inlinedoc` just sets a flag in the object being built.

I'll add a test for this for good measure.

----@class vim.treesitter.language.RequireLangOpts

+---@class vim.treesitter.language.add.Opts
+---@inlinedoc

 ---@field filetype? string|string[]

 ---@param lang string Name of the parser (alphanumerical and `_` only)
----@param opts (table|nil) Options:

----                          Defaults to {lang}.
----                        - path (string|nil) Optional path the parser is located at
----                        - symbol_name (string|nil) Internal symbol name for the language to load
+---@param opts vim.treesitter.language.add.Opts Options:

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -233,11 +234,33 @@ definitions.  The |lua-vim| :help is generated from the docstrings.
 
 Docstring format:
 - Use LuaCATS annotations: https://luals.github.io/wiki/annotations/
-- Limited markdown is supported.
-  - List-items start with `-` (useful to nest or "indent")
+- Markdown is supported.
 - Use ``` for code samples.
   Code samples can be annotated as `vim` or `lua`
 - Use `@nodoc` to prevent documentation generation.
+- Use `@inlinedoc` to inline `@class` blocks into `@param` blocks.
+  E.g. >lua
+      --- Object with fields:
+      --- @class myopts
+      --- @inlinedoc
+      ---
+      --- Documentation for some field
+      --- @field somefield? integer
+
+      --- @param opts? myOpts

comment_data.body: This is a great improvement!

@@ -233,11 +234,33 @@ definitions.  The |lua-vim| :help is generated from the docstrings.
 
 Docstring format:
 - Use LuaCATS annotations: https://luals.github.io/wiki/annotations/
-- Limited markdown is supported.
-  - List-items start with `-` (useful to nest or "indent")
+- Markdown is supported.
 - Use ``` for code samples.
   Code samples can be annotated as `vim` or `lua`
 - Use `@nodoc` to prevent documentation generation.
+- Use `@inlinedoc` to inline `@class` blocks into `@param` blocks.
+  E.g. >lua
+      --- Object with fields:
+      --- @class myopts
+      --- @inlinedoc
+      ---
+      --- Documentation for some field
+      --- @field somefield? integer
+
+      --- @param opts? myOpts
+      function foo(opts)
+      end
+<
+
+  Will be rendered as: >vimdoc
+
+      foo({opts})
+
+          Parameters:
+            - {opts}? (table) Object with the fields:
+                      - {somefield}? (integer) Documentation

comment_regular_data.body: @wookayin @clason @MariaSolOs would appreciate any feedback on this.

Hmm... I'm a bit torn. On the one hand, generating these is a big positive; on the other, they do clutter the documentation a lot, to the point of noticeably affecting readability.

Can we restructure these so the "option" classes go to a separate subsection at the end of the corresponding section (as "endnotes", if you will)? The top-level classes (especially diagnostics) should stay (near the beginning) in the section, though.

> Hmm... I'm a bit torn. On the one hand, generating these is a big positive; on the other, they do clutter the documentation a lot, to the point of noticeably affecting readability.

This is all very much tied to the quality of the code annotations we have. For some they are a bit cluttered, and I've already hidden quite a lot of them in this change with `(private)` and `@nodoc`.

I guess the biggest wins:
- vim.diagnostic structure is better documented
- lsp.txt is much improved IMO
- The reduce duplication in function options.

We can continue to hide more of the classes, I just want to be careful that we don't create any dead references.

> Can we restructure these so the "option" classes go to a separate subsection at the end of the corresponding section (as "endnotes", if you will)? The top-level classes (especially diagnostics) should stay (near the beginning) in the section, though.

A large majority of these are inlined, the ones that remain represent a small minority. The troublesome ones are the one from `diagnostic.lua` which I'm not sure how to present well.

The vim.lpeg ones can all be hidden.

The treesitter ones still need a bit of work.

I think the classes all need to go at the start **or** the end. If there's too many, then we either hide or inline them.

> This is all very much tied to the quality of the code annotations we have.

Oh, certainly; and having this tooling will give us _objective_ guidelines for improving that. (This, too, is very welcome.) I guess my question boils down to "how much of this can be done automatically in the tooling?"

> The treesitter ones still need a bit of work.

A _lot_ of work (in general).

> I think the classes all need to go at the start or the end.

Hmm; I do think it's useful here to distinguish and treat differently
1. actual classes that describe data structures that users/plugin writers may be expected to handle
2. "fake" classes that describe option tables.

I'd think that 1. should always be included, in the beginning, and 2. _may_ be included, but not in the beginning. (If that is at all feasible, with tooling and/or adapting the annotations.)

I've inlined a bunch more stuff included return values of the form `mytype[]`.

Does that look better?
It does; I did find the `TSQuery` documentation useful, though. But as you say: that help file has bigger problems.
Agree. This will need some iteration.
The inlined docs look good (much better, even)! ðŸ‘
While we're at it: is it possible to style inlined class fields as `{foo}` instead of plain "foo"?

Nice, thanks! Followup question, for the sake of completeness: what would be the best way of styling optional fields?
* `{field?}`
* `{field}?`
* `[{field}]` (which is the vimdoc convention for vimscript)

(Whichever we pick, I can try adapting the vimdoc parser for; the second option is probably the easiest to handle for me.)
`{field}?` seems like the best option to me.

> `{field}?` seems like the best option to me.

Agreed; pull request for vimdoc parser is ~~ready~~ merged. Could you add this to the developer guidelines?
I think we should also include an entry on `news.txt` for people that have been consuming these types.

title: docs: document Lua objects
